title: Themes and Symbols in the Celtic Legend of Peredur and their Connections to the Saga of Parsifal and the Grail Legend
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author discusses the parallels between the ancient Celtic legend of Peredur and the saga of Parsifal. The author explores the idea that both stories refer to ancient, non-Christian elements and spirits. The text then goes on to discuss the use of a powerful and lethal lance in ancient Celtic legends, which is also present in Wolfram's Parsifal. The lance is said to be infused with venomous blood that can put out flames. Similarly, in Wolfram's text, the lance is poisoned and cured by the "Royal Blood." This final part, XIX. EL "GOLPE DOLOROSO," examines the different forms of the motif of the invalid king and their symbolic significance.
content: Se disipan entonces las tinieblas y la tragedia, despierta la «memoria de la sangre» hiperbórea, que actúa como custodio de la espada. Se realiza el misterio de la «Sangre Regia». XIX. EL «GOLPE DOLOROSO» Examinemos ahora las varias formas adoptadas por el motivo del rey inválido, aparte la ya considerada en el caso de Amfortas. En el Grand Saint Graal y en la Queste du Graal, el rey ha sufrido heridas combatiendo contra un rey enemigo de los cristianos, el rey Crudel. Estas heridas no las nota hasta el momento en que pierde la vista, por haberse acercado demasiado al Grial. Podríamos interpretar el símbolo en el sentido de que la fallida realización del Grial lleva al reconocimiento de una inferioridad, de un haber sido «herido» sin saberlo en el acto de haber luchado contra los representantes de formas tradicionales no cristianas y quizá de haberlos visto.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the myth of the "Royal Blood" appears in different forms throughout various texts, including the concept of the invalid king with wounds received during battle. The symbolism suggests that the failure to achieve the Grail leads to a recognition of inferiority, while the sword held by the predestined waits to be wielded by someone who is qualified to do so. These myths serve as both cautionary tales and symbols of hope, reminding us that our fates are inextricably linked to our choices and actions.
